In both sites, women are organized in informal networks to undertake agricultural activities such as soil fertility management and crop harvesting. Women and men adhere to culturally established and differentiated gender roles, including with regard to the division of labour. Such differentiation is associated with the traditional pahari (i.e. mountain) identity of the Kumaoni people (e.g. Pokhriyal 1994; Badola and Hussain 2003; Mehta 2008; Ogra 2008), which place women at the centre of the agricultural system, while men are expected to participate in the cash economy mainly related to off-farm income generation. Furthermore, in this region, Kumaoni people are an ethnic group with a traditional caste system 1 that is still prevalent.
